intro: Oenothera boothii subsp. alyssoides, commonly known as the desert evening primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant has narrow, linear leaves and produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, wind-dispersed seeds. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. Oenothera boothii subsp. alyssoides is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in harsh desert conditions.
